Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Practices and Policies of Peri-urban Land Conversion

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research funded by this award examines peri-urban land and social transformations. The goal is to address broader questions about the current and future trajectories of agrarian societies in a world increasingly characterized by agricultural land dispossession, the conversion of rural lands to urban uses, and rural to urban migration. One outcome of these processes has been an increasing number of mega-cities, with populations in excess of 10 million residents, in places that formerly had longstanding agricultural economies. As cities grow, farmers lose land and livelihoods, and peri-urban city outskirts become informal settlements of concentrated poverty and underdevelopment. The research will address the following overarching questions: How do agrarian households that have lost agricultural land engage with the immense material and social changes to their lives? And how do their responses to land dispossession and land-use change, which can range from local-level coping to public protests and political engagement, figure into the process and strategy of urban development? Comprehensive inquiry on the micro- and macro-level implications of city expansion for those living on the urban margins is important because it will elucidate contempoary global developments in urbanization, land grabbing, and rural political movements. This knowledge will aid in future planning for politically, socially, and environmentally sustainable mega-cities.

The research will be carried out in peri-urban Hanoi, Vietnam, by Yale University anthropology doctoral student, Emily Nguyen, under the supervision of Dr. Erik Harms. Hanoi is an appropriate research site because recent Vietnamese economic reform policies and urban master plan strategies have driven large-scale conversions of agricultural land into industrial and high-end residential zones. The recentness and intensity of these developments will highlight, and thereby make more amenable to study, the relationships to be examined. Findings can then be extended to other sites around the world, including in the United States. The researcher will collect empirical data through a mixed-methods approach, which will include: semi-structured interviews stratified by gender and generation, the elicitation of oral histories, participant observation, archival document analysis, and land-use mapping. Results from the study will produce a theoretical and methodological platform for understanding how formal planning, informal practices of using space, and diversity in population response come together to transform agrarian landscapes. Findings also will be useful to policy makers undertaking capital-driven urban planning in a context with socialist agrarian histories.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Peri-urban zones, particularly those of many major cities in Asia, are an important site for capturing and theorizing on the dynamics of urban transformation and the ramifications of such processes for pre-existing agrarian land and livelihoods. These spaces, of intermixed rural-urban land use and economies, currently experience extensive agricultural land dispossession, rural to urban land conversion, and rural to urban migration. In a number of mega-cities around the globe, the large-scale recovery of agricultural land to accommodate urban growth and densification has led farmers to lose their primary sources of income, while at the same time, turning the peri-urban zones into areas of concentrated informal economies, underdevelopment, and environmental degradation. Living under such socio-economic and ecological conditions, farmers have responded to land recovery through public protests and legal actions. Concurrently, rural populations have also acquiesced as well as willingly participated in (and contributed to) such urban-oriented changes. This research seeks to investigate the complex macro-and micro-scale dynamics of peri-urban land and social transformation through anthropologically-grounded methods. It seeks to address the following overarching questions: How do agrarian households who have lost agricultural land to urbanization now engage with the immense material and social changes to their lives? And how do their diverse responses to land dispossession and land use change, figure into the process and strategy of urban development?

The field research that the Co-PI completed to address the latter inquiries was an ethnographic study on the lived experiences and emergent spatial economies of peri-urban villagers who live amidst agricultural land dispossession and urban expansion in the capital city of Hanoi, Vietnam. Hanoi is an ideal site for examining rural-urban transformations because recent Vietnamese economic reform policies and urban master plan strategies have driven large-scale conversions of agricultural land into industrial and high-end residential zones. The Co-PI spent eighteen months conducting interviews with peri-urban villagers, urban planners, and city officials to collect empirical data as well as personal narratives detailing Hanoi's land use changes. Fieldwork also included participant observation of various peri-urban villagers in their day-to-day agricultural and non-agricultural activities, and during village-related rituals and social gatherings. The Co-PI gathered geo-spatial and visual data of urban master plans and village land use change through both archival research and mapping activities in the peri-urban field sites. During her time in the field, she also attended numerous local and international conferences and workshops for academic researchers studying urbanization, where she had the opportunity to learn from scholars working on similar issues in China and other parts of Southeast Asia. 

The various data that the Co-PI collected during her ethnographic fieldwork pointed to a number of important socio-material factors that are integral to urbanization processes in Hanoi (as well as other Asian contexts) that will be considered in greater detail in the upcoming analysis and writing stage of her dissertation. Firstly, through conversations and daily engagement with peri-urban villagers, the Co-PI discovered the importance of considering "the village," as an enduring social structure and image of agrarian life, for the broader examination of contemporary urban changes. She found that village-and-state collaborations on heritage preservation of village relics and handicrafts re-link formerly agricultural villages to the city by re-defining their roles as living heirs and producers of Hanoi's agrarian history. Her analysis of urban planning strategies and actual village land use changes showed that spirituality--embodied in deity worship, as well as in village temples--contributed to many significant divergences and revisions of urban master plans. This study attended to both the competing discourses as well as intersecting sentiments (such as that of attachment, pride and fear) that enabled village practices and local spiritual sites to endure amidst urban development. By considering the combined discursive and affective forces of urban transformation, the dissertation will demonstrate how the less tangible emotive qualities of a social atmosphere may instigate very tangible social and spatial changes.

This research contributes to interdisciplinary examinations of mega city development by showing, through concrete ethnographic examples, how formal planning strategies, informal practices of using space, diverse population responses come together to transform agrarian landscapes.The results from this research can help to broaden current understandings of urbanization, land grabbing, and rural political movements occurring in Asia as well as across the developing world. As such, these findings may aid policy makers and urban developers engaged in the planning of sustainable mega-cities in places with longstanding agrarian histories.
